Description: One handled jug of light red pottery with bulbous body, rimmed neck and foot. Red-brown Nile silt, common erupted limestone inclusions upto 2mm and common fine mica, with some vesicles. Break on the rim shows common rounded quartz and frequent white inclusions. wheel-made with red slip.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Mercer Art Gallery, Harrogate. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

3rd to 2nd century BC parallels from Hadra, Alexandria (Enklaar 1998, 23, fig.20). Enklaar, A. 1998. Preliminary report on the pottery found at Hadra station, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 15-24. Vermeule, C. & von Bothmer, D. 1959, Notes on a New Edition of Michaelis: Ancient Marbles in Great Britain, part three: 2, American Journal of Archaeology 63 (4), p.329-348, pp.346 “Corinthian aryballos, from Naukratis (griffin-bird)”.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IC.111)
